                     Breadcrumbs                                  Home                                               Academics                                               Faculty                                               Pascal Menoret                                                          Pascal Menoret                                                                      Pascal Menoret                  Assistant Professor of Middle Eastern Studies                                Affiliation: NYU Abu Dhabi                                                 Biography      Pascal Menoret completed his Ph.D. in 2008 from the Department of History at the Université Paris 1 Panthéon-Sorbonne. He joined NYUAD in 2011 after two years as a post-doctoral fellow at Princeton’s Institute for the Transregional Study of the Contemporary Middle East, North Africa and Central Asia (2008-2010). Pascal was a scholar at the Harvard Academy for International and Area Studies (2010-2011 and 2013-2014).     Pascal's research combines urban history and social anthropology. His latest book, Joyriding in Riyadh: Oil, Urbanism, and Road Revolt , (Cambridge University Press, 2014) explores the relationship between urban planning and youth unrest in the Saudi capital. His new book project, entitled Graveyard of the Clerics: Religious Activism in Saudi Suburbia , is a cultural history of the Saudi Islamic movements since the mid-1960s. He has published The Saudi Enigma: A History (Zed Books, 2005) and L'Arabie, des routes de l'encens à l'ère du pétrole (Gallimard, 2010) .     Pascal is also interested in literary translation from Arabic into English, urban music in the Middle East and Southern Europe, and modern architecture. He created the NYUAD Translation Workshop, a group of students and faculty who collectively translate contemporary Arabic literature into English. He edited The Abu Dhabi Guide: Modern Architecture, 1968-1992 (FIND 2014), a guide to thirty modernist landmarks of the Emirati capital written by the students of the "Modern Architecture in Abu Dhabi" class.     Before his doctoral fieldwork in Riyadh (2005-2007), Pascal studied Arabic with Houda Ayoub in Paris and German philosophy with Gérard Lebrun at the Université de Provence. He wrote his M.A. thesis on a Saudi TV series, Tash Ma Tash, and his B.A. thesis on religion and politics in Hegel’s philosophy. He graduated from the Lycée Lacordaire in Marseille in 1994.                                         Current Courses       Emergence of the Modern Middle East   Society and Politics of Saudi Arabia   Politics and the City   Modern Architecture in Abu Dhabi                                                          Publications       See Full list       Books and Edited Volumes     Joyriding in Riyadh: Oil, Urbanism, and Road Revolt . Cambridge University Press, 2014.   L’Arabie, des routes de l’encens à l’ère du pétrole . Paris: Gallimard Découverte, 2010.       From Structural Violence to Violent Activism Around the Persian Gulf . Special Issue of The Muslim World, 101, 2, April 2011 (with Laurent Bonnefoy and Francois Burgat).   The Saudi Enigma: A History . London: Zed Books, 2005 (Original Version: L’énigme saoudienne. Les Saoudiens et le monde, 1744-2003. Paris: La Découverte, 2003. Also translated into Spanish and Italian.)    Journal Articles   “The Bleak Romance of Tahliya Street”. Middle East Journal of Culture and Communication , 6, 2013 (Co-authored with Nadav Samin).   “ Development, Planning and Urban Unrest in Saudi Arabia .” The Muslim World , 101, 2, April 2011.   “ Apprendre à voter? Le cas des élections saoudiennes de 2005 .” Genèses , 2009/4, 77.   “ Le cheikh, l’électeur et le SMS. Logiques électorales et mobilisation islamique en Arabie Saoudite .” Transcontinentales , 1, 2005.   “ De la rage à l’enthousiasme: le parcours d’un jeune électeur saoudien .” Chroniques Yéménites , 12, 2004.   “ Pouvoirs et oppositions en Arabie Saoudite: de la contestation armée àl’institutionnalisation de l’islamisme. ” Maghreb-Machrek , 177, 2003.   “Chronologie de l’Arabie Saoudite.” Chroniques Yéménites, 10, 11, 12, 13, 2002-2005.     “ Les murs de Riyad: islam et modernité urbaine en Arabie Saoudite .” Chroniques Yéménites, 9, 2001. (under pseudonym)    Book Chapters   “Leaving Islamic Activism Behind: Ambiguous Disengagement in Saudi Arabia.” In Joel Beinin and Frederic Vairel (dir.), Social Movements, Mobilization and Contestation in the Middle East and North Africa , Palo Alto: Stanford University Press, 2011.   “Rebels Without a Cause? A Politics of Deviance in Saudi Arabia” (with Abdullah al-Otaibi). In Linda Herrera and Asef Bayat (ed.). Being Young and Muslim. New Cultural Politics in the Global South and North . New York: Oxford University Press, 2010.   “Saudi Arabia.” In Ellen Lust (ed.). The Middle East . Washington: CQ Press, 2010.   “Urban Unrest and Non-religious Radicalization in Saudi Arabia.” In Madawi Al-Rasheed and Marat Shterin (eds.). Dying for Faith: Religiously Motivated Violence in the Contemporary World . London: I.B. Tauris, 2009.   “Fighting for the Holy Mosque. The 1979 Mecca Insurgency.” In Christine Fair and Sumit Ganguly (eds.). Treading on Sacred Ground: Counterinsurgency Operations in Sacred Spaces . New York: Oxford University Press, 2008.   “La constitution imaginaire de la jeunesse saoudienne: Islam et protestation en Arabie Saoudite.” In Mounia Bennani-Chraibi and Iman Farag (eds.), Jeunesses des pays arabes, par-delà les menaces et les promesses . Paris : CEDEJ, 2007.    Book Review   Review of Christopher Davidson, After the Sheikhs: The Coming Collapse of the Gulf Monarchies (Hurst & Co. 2012), The Middle East Journal , Vol. 68, no. 1, 2014.   Review of Jason Pine, The Art of Making Do in Naples (Minnesota University Press 2012), in City: Analysis of Urban Trends, Culture, Theory, Policy, Action , vol. 18, no. 1, 2014.   Review of Mansoor Jassem Alshamsi, Islam and Political Reform in Saudi Arabia: The Quest for Political Change and Reform (Routledge 2011), in Journal of Arabian Studies , vol. 3, 2013.
